author: BatMeckley
content:
You clearly have put in many years so hopefully the measuring and the protractor gives you that extra push to get to where you’re hoping to go 🤍.

Just trying to put context in here for the people that haven’t. None of the mixes in the mix off we had on the forum earlier hinged on the  single digit adjustments of the angle of the toe in of the speakers. It’s important to spend our times wisely on the things that matter most.

Virtually every kid I know that started on a $4000 guitar is less of a player than the kid that started on a squire. There’s something to learning the skills and then upgrading the tools.

author: peterlabberton
content:
So far I’m using the S1 to:

a) have hands on control when mixing drums, as I’ve got a handful of parallel compression and distortion auxes. I’ve made it work with a keyboard and mouse, but being able to have one hand on an audio track fader and the other on the return of a parallel effect is great.

b) setup VCAs for my whole mix and, once I’ve got things in a good spot, close all the pro tools windows so I’m more focused on just listening, and play the mix back and write automation.

These are both just things I’ve missed about working on a console, and I’m glad to be able to reincorporate them into my workflow.

And to put the EQ on, I sent my main PT output to a virtual output, and have the EQ on there in Console, assigned to the monitors.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: This was my first setup in 2010. All based around the Clavinova. I wanted one since I was 6 or so and then my parents parent promised to get it once I finished a certain level of the royal conservatory. Managed to record into it and then get that off into a computer. Eventually got a laptop and interface. Was a Presonus firewire one and my laptop wasn't happy with that. I remember many months of getting PCMCIA cards to try to et it to work without dropouts but never did and eventually got a computer from Rain Computers (anyone remember them?) with an old RME PCI interface

author: cian riordan
content: My advice for moving consoles would be pull all the channels and any backplane boards if you can. Take the legs off or separate the top frame from bottom. Wrap the empty top frame in packing blankets if you can. And just get more guys than you think you need and do it very slow.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Thank you!!

I will say - I got a good deal on this relative to a typical console buying experience. 30k for a console that I had spent two years using already, was fully functional (as fully functional as any vintage console) and it came with all the wiring and snakes and DL’s, and spare parts. And a local sale. 

I’m not sure I would’ve gone this route if it was more risky.

author: cian riordan
content:
Full setup:
Kick Bat: Sony ECM50
Kick Out 1: 47fet
Kick Out 2: Audix DX
Snr: 441
Toms: U87s
OH Mono: U47
OHs: U67
RMs: RCA 44s

All going through the Neve 34128’s. It’s really just a trial run for the new console but was fun to do an all-out splurge with the nice microphones. Nothing making up for my shitty playing tho 😛

author: Tim O’Sullivan
content: I love it. I don’t mix on it, and I use an Audient Nero for center section shit. But nice to have a fader to grab, and some utility eq’s. I mostly use my outboard pre’s and those all have little labs attenuators before the console so I have a ton of control over the headroom. I also use it to buss stuff down like kick mics and guitar amps to keep track counts down.

author: Zack Hames
content: Real talk, I DID NOT like SSL plugins of any kind until I used this console and heard what it can actually do. I still think the hardware absolutely crushes every plugin version (I really can't describe why either, it's just better) BUT having the perspective of the hardware experience allows me to use the plugins and chase what i know I want it to do much much easier.

author: peterlabberton
content:
This is the kind of nerdy tweaky shit I think this discord will appreciate: got my lil S1 control surface a few days ago, and used setting it up as an excuse to also play around with the arrangement of my tiny desk, and add some EQ to my monitors.

Tried the S1 behind my keyboard (too deep and potential for more reflections), and off to my left (weird neck craning all day), and landed here for now. Then busted out a mirror and angled my desk to avoid any reflections from the monitors at the listening position. Shot the room again and popped this EQ on the output in UAD Console (it’s finally good for something!!), and am very pleased with the new arrangement. 🎉

Ruairi might have a fit with this EQ curve, but I’m ABing it in and out and it’s definitely helpful, until I get my act together and build some membranes!

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I can't say enough good things about A32 tbh.  The converters are VERY good with no discernable difference between A32 and the RME UFX+  ...  but it's my mixer bridge more than modular.  The modular routes to an old Apogee, and can then MADI into the mixer (if you wanted to get real tweaky with EQ or use compressors).  

As far as levels go...    the A32 does something I had no experienced with other converters, and I love it.  You can adjust the sensitivy of the analog input...  Here's a better explanation from the manual

> The analog inputs of the A32 DANTE can each be set to different
> sensitivities. You can choose between three reference levels: +4dBu,
> +13dBu and +20dBu. Using the DSP, you can additionally set the
> reference levels from -8dBu to +20dBu in 1 dB steps. The DSP always
> calculates the optimum configuration. For example, if you set +12dBu,
> the analog reference will be set to +13dBu and the signal will be
> attenuated by 1dB.

That would work magic with eurorack levels.  I use it sometimes so that I can overdrive the Trident and keep the channel direct outputs under the limiter's clipping stage. Helps when you want to be abusive in analgo but not worry about converters clipping.

author: Zack Hames
content:
So, I will be needing to move my SSL 40 channel E series console down these stairs. 

Previous owner said to get a moving company to move it down the stairs - I think that’s the move, but wanted to inquire here with what anyone else has done in this scenario, or any other tips.

author: hyanrarvey
content: I’d lay plywood down and slide the console down btw or long wide foam blocks

author: Zack Hames
content:
Consoles 9’ long
It’ll fit through the door; it’s under 32” without the legs

author: BatMeckley
content: Also saving a couple bucks on movers to safely transport what once was a console worth well into the 6 figure range seems short sighted

author: Zack Hames
content:
Yeah I haven’t ran the DL snakes yet, I have to address a +18 volt issue the console isn’t seeing. I’ll fix that tonight and then start running everything. 

It is not super convenient having the patchbay on the right and the interfaces and outboard on the left; but the right side there’s a door that goes to a booth, right where I’d want stuff. 

I *may* put the interfaces on the right side in the corner. We will see

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not sure what I’m gonna do long term. I like them on the meter bridge, at least in the old studio, because they’re closer to my ears that way. In the old studio I experimented having them on stands behind the desk but it put the speakers weirdly far and that room didn’t carry the sound well. 

I may do cinder block stands behind the console if I like how they sound in that position then I can put my ns10’s on the meter bridge stands

author: cian riordan
content: When you're done hemhoragging money on your install, I'd suggest sound anchors to hold the speakers. They will give you more flexibility over cinder blocks, allow you to lever the speakers over the console if you like, and will decouple them from the desk so you're not feeling the low end through your fingers/hands.

author: cian riordan
content: Also something I'll often do on large consoles when I'm in bigger studios, I'll just drag the NS-10s to the left side of the console while I'm getting drum sounds (CH1 = Kick, Ch2 = SNR, etc). I find myself making the most critical phase/EQ decisions there to begin with, might as well have a separate little sweetspot for it.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m glad to hear the sound anchors will do that - that was my long term goal in my mind because, like you said, you can put them OVER the console a bit. And it’ll be worth it. 

Thanks for the suggestions dude - I’ve got a lot to learn and figure out. I’ll take all the help I can get.
